pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces a linter to flag uses of `refine'`, suggesting to use `refine` instead.

`refine` and `refine'` are similar tactics, but they handle meta-variable slightly differently.  This means that they are not completely interchangeable, but `refine` is more readable and (heuristically) tends to be more efficient on average.

This linter is an incentive to discourage uses of `refine'`, without being a ban.

[Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Usage.20of.20refine').

---

nodes.body: !bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/fa328a88-c2b0-4b34-b2bd-1ad105f19b7e) for commit 634b5d00003695c7f0ac2eb9df9c078246b09add.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/e5e02515-061c-4ac7-adc3-96a401f0a0a1/to/fa328a88-c2b0-4b34-b2bd-1ad105f19b7e) against commit e5450096b074b32faf8bb81d0d3bb16a691335c1.

### PR summary [19e6497823](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11884/commits/19e64978237e8d01920137b9147e13a6d9969881)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
Too many changes (3989)!

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ getLinterHash`
`+ getRefine'`
`+ refineLinter`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

I am benching a simpler version of this linter at #13806.  I left in that PR the `refine'` that this one fixed, as a small scale test that the simpler algorithm still catches the same issues!

EDIT: the test was successful, so I incorporated the simplification to the code in the other PR into this one.

For the record/anybody coming here later: this was discussed multiple times on zulip, including
[in late 2023](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/refine.20vs.20refine'),
[in spring 2024](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Usage.20of.20refine')
and [in summer 2024](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Status.20of.20.60refine'.60). The last thread focused more on the final removal of `refine'` and having a linter against it

  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10019722792/job/27696588119)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

The implementation looks good to me, with some minor tweaks applied.
You have a merge conflict, and perhaps some further occurrences crept in on master... with all these addressed, feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf.

I'm not sure if zulip already had consensus on landing this weak linter. Perhaps the warning will need rewording... yet, I think this deserves a further look.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
Should this mention that you sometimes need `apply` for performance?
I added mention of `apply`, thanks!

```suggestion
# The "refine" linter

```suggestion
The "refine" linter flags usages of the `refine'` tactic.

```suggestion
/-- `getRefine' t` returns all usages of the `refine'` tactic in the input syntax `t`. -/
Would you like to use `@inherit_doc` here, perhaps on an expanded doc-string?
I recycled part of the module doc and used `inherit_doc`.  Thanks!
How about something like "The refine' tactic is discouraged: please strongly consider using `refine` or `apply` instead."
I also went with your wording.

Let me double-check I understood this correctly. (Up to you if you would like to include some of this as comments.)
- If we have a syntax node with arguments, we recurse into the arguments, finding all `refine'`s there.
- If the current node is a `refine'`, we flag that one also.
- The first arm returns `args` (which is empty when no `refine'` is found).
- If `t` is something else, it cannot contain any `refine'`
I wonder about the last bullet; if this overlooks something. Otherwise, makes sense to me.

The other constructors for `Syntax` are `.missing`, `.atom` and `.ident`: the `refine'` tactic nests inside it some of those, but they are all subnodes/leaves of a `.node` with kind `Lean.Parser.Tactic.refine'`.  Conclusion: I do not think that this leaves out anything!

```suggestion
The tactics `refine` and `refine'` are similar, but they handle meta-variables slightly differently.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add the refine linter, to flag uses of `refine'`
